She drove to it on a Thursday, only to find loitering outside was Doug Kennedy one of her problem students. She was nervous exiting her car, and kept her head down to try and avoid any confrontation. Her short stature made her feel very easily intimidated. Doug, noticing her smiled to herself.

"Heya Gwen! Going to buy some flied lice are you?? You bringing that home to Jackie Chan?"

Gwen started to well up. She just didn't feel confident. Doug started pressuring her into the corner. Just then the shopkeeper showed up, a small Asian man. His presence was enough to spook Doug away. And with a smirk he said "I'll see you tomorrow Ms Ling."

The shopkeeper just smiled. "You struggle with confidence Gwen?"

You need to try this tea. Secret tea. It will help with your confidence issue." The shopkeeper winked. "Do me a favour and head home. Relax, drink some of this secret tea. You'll soon be feel happy. Trust."

Quickly, he tossed the cover aside and got up. He walked over to the window in a hasty fashion and hid the blinding light behind the pull down shades.

"I feel so miserable, what happened?" He said to no one. Looking around, he recognized his surroundings.

"My room? Was I asleep?"

With that, he decided to go to the bathroom and wash his face. After a short jaunt through the hallway, he found the bathroom door. It was nearly closed, so he took his hand a pushed it open, but he stopped for a second when he noticed something strange about his hand.

"Hmmm, my nails need to be filed badly."

He said in a tired voice. Feeling as terrible as he did, he put it in the back of his mind and continued into the bathroom. He placed himself in front of the mirror and flipped the light switch on.

"You look terrible Natsuko."

James' reflection was fairly depressing, his long black hair was in a mess, his eyes were drooping, and his lips were pale.

"I look worse than I did when I tried to put make up on for the first time."

Looking down, he noticed that he was in his school uniform, and skirt and blouse.

"I forgot to take it off? Did I get knocked out today?"

He raised a hand and turned on the faucet before filling his hands with water. Just before he was about to throw the water on his face, he noticed something dangling from the bracelet on his arm.

"Is that, an envelope?"

It was; there was a sealed envelope hanging off his bracelet. He emptied his hands, trying not to splash any water on his uniform, and then pulled the envelope off the string it was hanging from. On the front, it simply said "To James" with no address or postage. James opened it, and found a hand written letter composed in kanji inside.

"James, I did not appreciate your mocking me behind my back. It can be quite difficult trying to get used to another country even without people as rude as you. I think it's only fitting that you go through what I did. If you are reading this, I am already back in Japan. You won't be able to reach me, but I can get to you if I want."

As soon as he finished the letter, James became aware of how strange everything had been since he woke up.

"I, I just called myself Natsuko before. But I"

"But...no, no, I'm not Natsuko, my name is..."

He just stood for a minute, but nothing came to mind, it was only when he looked down at the letter again that he remembered.

"I'm James."

In his mind, James struggled fiercely to bring his memories to the surface. He needed to confirm his identity; no matter how right it felt, he knew his name was not Natsuko, he knew he wasn't some Japanese girl. But all that he could recall was growing up in his far off homeland. Memories of people, places, and events that he could not find in his current place of residence soon rose up from the depths of mind in waves. He remembered his first festival when he was only a little girl, and all the gossip in girl's locker room when he first entered high school.

"I miss home."

Just then he jumped back in shock at his own words, not even noticing that he had spoken in japanese instead of english. He rose a hand to slap himself, but by the time his hand reached his soft cheek, the force behind it had faded to a light tap.

"Maybe, this is really me?"

He said as he stared at his reflection. After a few seconds, Natsuko looked down at the letter again. Rereading it, she could vaguely visualize a boy making fun of Mrs.Ling, but she couldn't tell if she was the boy or not.

"Would I really do that to Ling-sensei?

James was just too confused, he ran back to bed to lay down, not even bothering to remove his school blouse and skirt like he usually insisted on whenever he wanted to sleep.

James was in his physics class trying to pay attention to the boring topic at hand, until the intercom went off.

"Can James Smith please go to room 5C now." The principal's voice sounded raspy.

He made his way to the room and knocked on the door. There was no answer. He knocked again. Nothing. He decided to enter the room himself, creaking the door open. It was dark with a single person standing at the front.

She was a middle-aged woman in her early forties. She wore a long skirt and a high pair of boots. A jacket covered the flower decorated blouse. Her hair was frizzy which suited her eccentric style. Her eyes were lit and blazing like candles. Around her neck was a chain and on it a crescent shaped trinket. James recognized her.

"Mom! What is it?! Is something wrong!?" he asked.

"No," she said. "Nothings wrong. Except your report card. It came in the mail today and it seems you failed half of your classes."

James gulped. He never saw his mother act this way.

"I came down here to sort it all out," she continued. "But it seems like you deserved to fail your subjects. You haven't been paying attention in class, you've been disrespectful to teachers. Well, that ends here. I won't have you a dropout like your sister. No. You will be successful. Even if I have to get you there myself. This time I am in control."

The crescent shape trinket started to glow. Then James blanked out. When he awoke...

You walked slowly to the principal's office with worry. You had a feeling you knew why you were called and it had to have something to do with your grades. In this school, they took every student's grades seriously. Of course, you did well in the beginning, but then over time, you started to become a "little" lazy. It seems that laziness has finally now caught up with you.

Sighing, you held your breath and told yourself to get this over with. The principal was likely going to lecture you a bit, then you'd have to promise you would clean your act up, and you would then be well back on your way.

Entering your office, you froze in place to see someone unexpected. Your mother, Becky  .

You turned red in shame, not only to the fact that the principal had called your mother but that she was...less conservative than most mothers you knew. You were never ready to go with her anywhere in public.

"Uh...hi mom," you gulped.

Your mother stared at you disapprovingly as she sat on the office couch just across from the principal's desk. "Hello sweetie. I'm very disappointed in you, right now."

'Clearly,' you thought.

The principal, seemingly unaffected by your mother's choice of apparel cleared her throat and stared daggers at you, much harsher than your mother's stare. Her hands were clasped together with her elbows across the table.

"James, I assume you know why I called you and your mother here," she began.

You nodded hesitantly. "My...grades?"

The principal nodded. "Yes, that is correct. You are on the track to failing Calculus and Chemistry which are necessary."

Becky frowned considerably to you, adding guilt. "Young man, you knew about this and yet, you didn't tell me. I didn't raise you just to fail two of your classes. I could have helped you on this if you had just been truthful to me."

You internally groaned. "I...I know mom, but you were expecting so much of me. I...I didn't want to disappoint you."

Becky closed her eyes and hummed. "Sweetie, I do expect a lot from you...and that includes getting help when you need it."

"We've been discussing some solutions to help you get back on track. We're giving you two options, James. There are no alternatives or discussion regarding this matter. You'll either be homeschooled for a month until you take a make-up exam or you'll let your mother join you in school everyday to keep an eye on you and ensure you're studying well. What will it be?"

You widened your eyes. Both of those options involved being under the watch or care of your mother...publicly or privately. You looked at your mother who stared at you, awaiting your answer.
